The number of measures this sequence takes is 7.

To determine this you would need to first count the total duration for each note in beats, then divide that into the measure length (in our case 4 beats per measure). In order from the start of the list the notes durations are as follows:
* Eighth Note = 1 beat / * 2-beat whole note + half beat rest /
* Quarter Note = 1 beat / * 3 beat whole note /
* Whole Note = 2 beats / * 5 beat whole note + quarter note /
* Eighth Note = 1 beat / * 6 beats /
* Half Note = 2 beats / * 8 beats /
* Sixteenth Note = 0.5 beats / * 16 beats /
* Whole Note = 2 beats / * 9 beats /
* Half Note = 2 beats / * 10 beats /
* Whole Note = 2 beats / * 11 beats /
* Whole Note = 2 beats / * 12 beats /
* Quarter Note = 1 beat / * 13 beats /

As we've now counted all the notes, it turns out they take up 7 measures.

If this had been written in 4/4 time signature instead the same sequence would have taken up 9 measures. This is because each measure in 4/4 has 4 beats rather than 2 like 2/2. So e.g., the eight notes will last one beat, whereas the sixteenth notes will last 0.5 beats. Thus the calculation becomes:
(1+1+1+1) + ((2*(0.5))+(0.5)+(2)*(0.
